Description: Limestone standing figure or female or child, broken at neck. Head fragment Surface discoloured (dirty), no obvious traces of paint.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Spurlock Museum, University of Illinois. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Three similar small archaising Hellenistic heads in limestone are known from Naukratis (Amsterdam, Allard Pierson Museum 7835; Champaign, Spurlock Museum, University of Illinois 1926.02.0032; Cambridge, Fitzwilliam Museum GR.3.1899), and are part of a small group of later limestone figures brought to Naukratis from Cyprus (British Museum GR1900,0214.22; Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1886.457; AN1896-1908-G.1042; Champaign, Spurlock Museum 1926.02.0029; Bristol, City Art Gallery & Museum H446.c). Naukratis parallel dated as 'probably archaizing work of late Hellenistic date or slightly later' (Budde & Nicholls 1967, no. 77/80, pl. 26). Beer, C. 1994. ‘Temple-boys: A study of Cypriote votive sculpture’. Studies in Mediterranean Archaeology. Vol. CXIII, Stockholm. Budde, L. and Nicholls, R. 1967. Catalogue of the Greek and Roman sculpture in the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (CD.133) (Phase 3)
